abstract.p: An improved sinker for circular hosiery knitting machines, with high resistance to the danger of damage causable by contiguous needles. The sinker (1) comprises a laminar body (2) which can be arranged on a vertical plane that passes through the axis (3a) of the needle cylinder (3) of a circular hosiery knitting machine between two contiguous needles (7) of the machine which are accommodated in respective axial slots (6) defined on the lateral surface of the needle cylinder (3). Each one of the needles (7) is movable with a reciprocating motion along the corresponding axial slot (6) with respect to the needle cylinder (3). The laminar body (2) has, on its front side, intended to be directed toward the axis (3 a) of the needle cylinder (3), a nose (8) which defines, with its upper side, the knockover plane (9) of the sinker (1). The sides (30) of the laminar body (2), in their regions intended to be superimposed laterally on the paths (12) of the contiguous needles (7) as a result of the reciprocating motion of the needles (7) along the corresponding axial slots (6) of the needle cylinder (3) and of the reciprocating motion of the sinker (1), on its plane of arrangement, toward and away from the axis (3 a) of the needle cylinder (3), have a continuous flat surface.

L'invention concerne une platine améliorée destinée à des machines à tricoter circulaires de bonneterie, avec une résistance élevée au risque d'endommagement pouvant être provoqué par des aiguilles contiguës. La platine (1) comprend un corps laminaire (2) qui peut être disposé sur un plan vertical qui passe à travers l'axe (3a) du cylindre d'aiguille (3) d'une machine à tricoter circulaire de bonneterie entre deux aiguilles contiguës (7) de la machine qui sont logées dans des fentes axiales (6) respectives définies sur la surface latérale du cylindre d'aiguille (3). Chacune des aiguilles (7) peut être déplacée avec un mouvement alternatif le long de la fente axiale (6) correspondante par rapport au cylindre d'aiguille (3). Le corps laminaire (2) comporte, sur sa face frontale, prévue pour être dirigée en direction de l'axe (3 a) du cylindre d'aiguille (3), un nez (8) qui définit, avec son côté supérieur, le plan d'abattage (9) de la platine (1). Les côtés (30) du corps laminaire (2), dans leurs régions prévues pour être superposées dans le sens latéral sur les chemins (12) des aiguilles contiguës (7) en conséquence du mouvement alternatif des aiguilles (7) le long des fentes axiales (6) correspondantes du cylindre d'aiguille (3) et du mouvement alternatif de la platine (1), sur son plan d'agencement, vers et à l'écart de l'axe (3 a) du cylindre d'aiguille (3), ont une surface plate continue.

description.p: IMPROVED SINKER FOR CIRCULAR HOSIERY KNITTING MACHINES, WITH HIGH RESISTANCE TO THE DANGER OF DAMAGE CAUSABLE BY CONTIGUOUS NEEDLES
The present invention relates to an improved sinker for circular hosiery knitting machines, with high resistance to the danger of damage causable by contiguous needles.

As is known, in hosiery knitting machines the knockover sinkers, termed sinkers hereinafter for the sake of simplicity, cooperate with the needles in forming stitches. The sinkers are arranged between the needles of the machine and have the function of defining a resting surface for the yarn supplied to the needles while they are forming a new loop of knitting and then of tensioning the loop of knitting against the shank of the needle while it is being moved to pick up the yarn in order to form a new loop of knitting, so as to produce assuredly the opening of the tab or tongue of the needle while the old loop of knitting is lowered on the shank of the needle.

In circular hosiery knitting machines, the sinkers are accommodated individually inside a radial slot defined in the sinker ring, which is fixed coaxially to the needle cylinder proximate to its upper end. Each sinker is arranged between two contiguous needles and is provided with at least one heel which protrudes upwardly from the corresponding slot of the sinker ring. Such heel engages in paths defined by cams which are connected to a sinker cover which faces the sinker ring in an upward region. The paths defined by such cams are shaped so as to produce, as a consequence of the actuation of the needle cylinder with a rotary motion about its own axis with respect to the sinker cover, a movement of the sinkers along a radial direction, in the conesponding slot, with respect to the needle cylinder.

Several types of sinkers are known which have different shapes according to the processes for which they are to be used. In their classic shape, the sinkers, one of which is shown by way of example in Figures 10 and 11 and is generally designated by the reference numeral 50, are
constituted by a laminar body 51, which is provided at the front, i.e., on its side intended to be directed toward the needle cylinder axis, with a nose 52 which defines, with its upper side, the so-called knockover plane 53, i.e., the plane on which the yarn taken at a feed or drop of the machine by the needle that lies between two contiguous sinkers 50 rests during the lowering of the needle to form a new loop of knitting.

Above the nose 52, the sinker 50 has a hook-shaped beak 54, which is directed toward the front side of the sinker 50, and between the beak 54 and the upper side or knockover plane 53 of the nose 52 of the sinker 50 a groove 55 is provided, by means of which the sinker 50, in its advancement motion toward the axis of the needle cylinder, engages the portion of knitting that lies between two contiguous needles in order to tension the loop of knitting, formed previously, against the shank of the needle while such needle is rising to take the yarn provided at a feed or drop of the machine.

On the upper side of the sinker 50, to the rear of the nose 52, the heel 56 is provided, which is intended to protrude upwardly from the sinker ring and to engage the path or paths defined by the actuation cams of the sinkers connected to the sinker cover.
It should be noted that the spatial references of the sinker, such as

"above" and "below", used in the present description and in the claims, for the sake of greater clarity, refer to the position of the sinker when it is in use in a circular hosiery knitting machine and is arranged in the sinker ring.
The sinker 50 is intended to rest, by means of its lower side 57, which is substantially flat, on the bottom of the radial slot of the sinker ring in which it is accommodated.

Below the nose 52 a guiding tab 58 is generally provided, which is separated from the nose 52 by a slot 59 which passes laterally through the sinker 50 and is open on the front side of the sinker 50. The slot 59 protrudes from the front side toward the rear side of the sinker. The guiding
tab 58, when the sinker 50 is inserted in the sinker ring, engages below an abutment, which is defined by a guiding ring which is fixed internally and coaxially to the needle cylinder and prevents the lifting of the front part of the sinker 50 due to the reaction of the yarn when the sinker 50 is pushed toward the axis of the needle cylinder in order to tension the loop of knitting against the shank of the needle.

The presence of the slot 59 between the nose 59 and the guiding tab 58 has the function of allowing the advancement of the sinker 50 toward the axis of the needle cylinder, so that the guiding tab 58 can penetrate below the portion of the guiding ring that defines the above mentioned abutment and which, during the advancement of the sinker 50, indeed penetrates in the slot 59 of the sinker 50.
Such known types of sinkers can cause problems upon an accidental breakage of the needles that lie to the side of the sinker.

In conventional sinkers, the slot 59 located between the nose 52 and the guiding tab 58 in fact is extended to the region of the sinker that faces directly the needles between which the sinker is arranged. When one of these two needles breaks, the cause of the breakage, which is generally constituted by a lateral impact of the needle against an unexpected obstacle, also causes a slight lateral bending of the needle. The region of the needle that is most subject to breakage is the region proximate to the head or hook of the needle, generally at the pivoting point of the tab of the needle. After breakage, the needle, in its reciprocating motion along the corresponding axial slot of the needle cylinder, is very likely to strike with its upper end, which is broken and bent laterally, the lower side 60 of the nose 52 of the sinker 50. There is also the possibility that the needle might strike, with its broken end, the lower side 57 of the sinker at the guiding tab 58.

These impacts can cause a deformation of the sinker which brakes the sliding of the sinker along the corresponding radial slot of the sinker ring, diversifying the tensioning effect of the loops of knitting performed by the
damaged sinker with respect to the effect produced by the sinkers that are still intact. The different tensioning effect, on the finished product, becomes apparent by means of a linear shape at the row of loops of knitting to the forming of which the damaged sinker cooperated. Such linear shape is not acceptable and causes the article to be rejected.

The aim of the present invention is to solve the above mentioned problems, by providing a sinker that can avoid or at least reduce the possibility of damage by the contiguous needles upon their accidental breakage.
Within this aim, an object of the invention is to provide a sinker which, by withstanding damage, ensures correct operation and therefore reduces the percentage of rejects on the finished product.
Another object of the invention is to provide a sinker that ensures high reliability in operation.
Another object of the invention is to provide a sinker that can be manufactured with competitive costs.

This aim, as well as these and other objects which will become better apparent hereinafter, are achieved by an improved sinker for circular hosiery knitting machines, comprising a laminar body which can be arranged on a vertical plane that passes through the axis of the needle cylinder of a circular hosiery knitting machine between two contiguous needles of the machine which are accommodated in respective axial slots defined on the lateral surface of the needle cylinder, each one of said needles being movable with a reciprocating motion along the corresponding axial slot with respect to the needle cylinder; said laminar body having, on its front side, intended to be directed toward the axis of the needle cylinder, a nose which defines, with its upper side, the knockover plane of the sinker, characterized in that the sides of said laminar body, in their regions intended to be superimposed laterally on the paths of the contiguous needles as a result of the reciprocating motion of the needles along the corresponding axial slots
of the needle cylinder and of the reciprocating motion of the sinker, on its plane of arrangement, toward and away from the axis of the needle cylinder, have a continuous flat surface.

Further characteristics and advantages of the invention will become better apparent from the description of a preferred but not exclusive embodiment of the sinker according to the invention, illustrated by way of non-limiting example in the accompanying drawings, wherein:

Figure 1 is a schematic perspective view, with some components omitted for the sake of simplicity and for greater clarity, of a sector of a circular hosiery knitting machine provided with sinkers according to the invention;

Figure 2 is a schematic top plan view, with some elements omitted for the sake of simplicity and for greater clarity, of a sector of a circular hosiery knitting machine provided with sinkers according to the invention;
Figure 3 is a sectional view of Figure 2, taken along the line ΙΠ-ΙΠ;
Figure 4 is an enlarged-scale view of a detail of Figure 3;
Figure 5 is a sectional view of Figure 2, taken along the line V-V; Figure 6 is an enlarged-scale view of a detail of Figure 5;

Figure 7 is a side elevation view of a sinker according to the invention with a needle adjacent to it in one of the possible mutual positions that can be assumed during operation in a circular hosiery knitting machine;
Figure 8 is a view, similar to Figure 7, of a sinker according to the invention with a needle broken proximate to its head or hook adjacent to it;
Figure 9 is a perspective view of the same situation as Figure 8;

Figure 10 is a side elevation view of the same situation of Figures 8 and 9 but with a conventional sinker, shown in solid lines and with the contour of a sinker according to the invention, drawn in broken lines, superimposed thereon;

Figure 1 1 is a perspective view, only for a sinker of the conventional type, of the situation shown in Figure 10.
With reference to Figures 1 to 9, the sinker according to the invention, generally designated by the reference numeral 1 , comprises a laminar body 2, which is intended to be arranged, in a circular hosiery knitting machine, on a vertical plane that passes through the axis 3 a of the needle cylinder 3.

More particularly, the sinker 1 according to the invention, like the sinkers 50 of the known type, is intended to be accommodated inside a radial slot 4, which is defined in the sinker ring 5, which is fixed externally and coaxially to the needle cylinder 3 of the hosiery knitting machine proximate to its upper end.

The needle cylinder 3 is arranged so that its axis 3 a is vertical and has, on its lateral surface, a plurality of axial slots 6, each of which accommodates a needle 7, which can be actuated, in a per se known manner, with a reciprocating motion along the corresponding axial slot 6, with respect to the needle cylinder 3, in order to form knitting.

The radial slots 4 of the sinker ring 5 are angularly offset with respect to the axial slots 6 of the needle cylinder 3 so that each radial slot 4 lies between two contiguous axial slots 6 and therefore so that each sinker 1 lies between two contiguous needles 7.

The laminar body 2 of the sinker 1 has, on its front side, i.e., the side intended to be directed toward the axis 3 a of the needle cylinder 3 when the sinker 1 is mounted on the circular hosiery knitting machine, a nose 8, which defines, with its upper side, the knockover plane 9 of the sinker 1.

The laminar body 2 is further provided with a hook-shaped beak 10, which lies above the knockover plane 9 and is directed with its tip toward the front side of the sinker 1 , so that a groove 1 1 which is open toward the front side of the sinker 1 is defined between the beak 10 and the knockover plane 9.

According to the invention, the sides 30 of the laminar body 2 of the sinker 1 , in their regions which, during the operation of the sinker 1
installed on the machine, are laterally superimposed on the paths 12 of the contiguous needles 7 due to the reciprocating motion of the needles 7 along the corresponding axial slots 6 of the needle cylinder 3 and due to the reciprocating motion of the laminar body 2 of the sinker 1, on its plane of arrangement, toward and away from the axis 3 a of the needle cylinder 3, have a continuous flat surface.

Substantially, the sinker 1 according to the invention does not have the slot 59 that in conventional sinkers 50 separates the nose 52 from the guiding tab 58. In this manner, in the sinker 1 according to the invention, since the upper side of the slot 59 or lower side 60 of the nose 52 that is present in conventional sinkers 50 is not present, one side of possible impact for the upper end of a contiguous broken needle 7 is entirely absent.

The laminar body 2 of the sinker 1 according to the invention is in any case provided with a guiding tab 13, which protrudes from the front side of the laminar body 2 with respect to the nose 8 and which, when the sinker

1 is mounted on the machine, due to the reciprocating motion of the sinker 1 along the corresponding radial slot 4, engages below an abutment 14 defined by a guiding ring 15, which is fixed coaxially and internally to the needle cylinder 3 of the hosiery knitting machine, proximate to its upper end, as shown in particular in Figures 5 and 6.
Conveniently, the laminar body 2 has, to the rear of the nose 8, an actuation heel 16, which protrudes from the upper side of the laminar body

2 and can engage cams for the actuation of the sinkers which are supported by a sinker cover, of a known type and not shown for the sake of simplicity, which in hosiery knitting machines faces in an upward region the sinker ring 5.

Advantageously, the laminar body 2 has, proximate to its rear side, an alignment heel 17, which protrudes from the lower side 18 of the laminar body 2 and defines a shoulder 19 which is substantially perpendicular to the lower side 18 of the laminar body 2 and can engage against a
circumferential edge 20 of the sinker ring 5 that is directed away from the axis 3 a of the needle cylinder 3 of the circular hosiery knitting machine.

The presence of the shoulder 19 makes it possible to arrange precisely the sinkers 1 in the condition of maximum approach to the axis 3a of the needle cylinder 3, safely avoiding the danger of interference of the sinkers 1 with the dial 21 arranged above and coaxially with respect to the needle cylinder 3.

The machine shown by way of example in the accompanying drawings is constituted by a machine with a needle cylinder 3 and a dial 21 also provided with needles 22 which are arranged inside radial slots 23 defined in the dial 21 and can be actuated, in a per se known manner, with a reciprocating motion along the radial slots 23 that accommodate them.

Advantageously, as shown in Figure 7, in the sinker 1 according to the invention the distance D between the knockover plane 9 and the lower side 18 of the laminar body 2 is greater than the maximum distance F from the same knockover plane 9 of the pivoting axis 24 of the tab 25 of the needles 7 arranged in the needle cylinder 3 during the maximum lowering that can be imparted to the needles 7, along the corresponding axial slot 6, to form a new loop of knitting.

In this manner, the region of the needles 7 arranged in the needle cylinder 3 that is most frequently subject to breakage, i.e., the region where the tab 25 is pivoted to the shank of the needle 7, is never located below the lower side 18 of the sinkers 1 and therefore, upon an accidental breakage in this region, the needle 7 cannot interfere even with the lower side 18 of the sinker 1.

As shown in Figure 10, which illustrates the comparison between a conventional sinker 50 and a sinker 1 according to the invention, the vertical space occupation of the sinker 1 according to the invention, at the knockover plane 9, is greater than the space occupation, in the same region, of a conventional sinker 50. For this reason, machines intended to be
provided with sinkers 1 according to the invention have radial slots 4 defined in the sinker ring 5 which are deeper or in any case are located further downwardly than those of machines of the known type, so that the knockover plane 9 of the sinkers 1 according to the invention is in the same position, with respect to the needles 7, as the knockover plane 53 of conventional sinkers on hosiery knitting machines of the known type.

In practice, in the sinker 1 according to the invention, due to the fact that at least in the regions of the sides of the sinker 1 that are superimposed laterally on the path 12 of the contiguous needles 7 no slot 59 is provided, but indeed there is a continuous smooth surface, the danger of interference with the upper end of the needles 7 if the needles 7 break accidentally proximate to the tip or head 26 of the needles 7 is avoided. Moreover, due to the fact that the lower side 18 of the sinker 1 according to the invention, in the machine on which it is fitted, is always located below the region at the pivoting axis 24 of the tab 25 to the shank of the contiguous needles 7, the danger of interference between the upper end of the needles 7 and the lower side 18 of the sinker 1 if the needles 7 break accidentally at this region is avoided as well.

In practice it has been found that the sinker according to the invention fully achieves the intended aim and objects, since it avoids or at least reduces the possibility of damage by the needles upon accidental breakage of the needles, ensuring correct operation and therefore reducing the percentage of rejects on the finished product.

Although the sinker according to the invention has been shown mounted on a circular hosiery knitting machine with cylinder and dial, it can be used with circular hosiery knitting machines without a dial.

The sinker thus conceived is susceptible of numerous modifications and variations, all of which are within the scope of the appended claims. All the details may further be replaced with other technically equivalent elements.
In practice, the materials used, as well as the dimensions, may be any according to requirements and to the state of the art.
The disclosures in Italian Patent Application No. MI2011A000314 from which this application claims priority are incorporated herein by reference.

Where technical features mentioned in any claim are followed by reference signs, those reference signs have been included for the sole purpose of increasing the intelligibility of the claims and accordingly such reference signs do not have any limiting effect on the interpretation of each element identified by way of example by such reference signs.

claim.claim-text: 1. An improved sinker (1) for circular hosiery knitting machines, comprising a laminar body (2) which can be arranged on a vertical plane that passes through the axis (3 a) of the needle cylinder (3) of a circular hosiery knitting machine between two contiguous needles (7) of the machine which are accommodated in respective axial slots (6) defined on the lateral surface of the needle cylinder (3), each one of said needles (7) being movable with a reciprocating motion along the corresponding axial slot (6) with respect to the needle cylinder (3); said laminar body (2) having, on its front side, intended to be directed toward the axis (3a) of the needle cylinder (3), a nose (8) which defines, with its upper side, the knockover plane (9) of the sinker (1), characterized in that the sides (30) of said laminar body (2), in their regions intended to be superimposed laterally on the paths (12) of the contiguous needles (7) as a result of the reciprocating motion of the needles (7) along the corresponding axial slots (6) of the needle cylinder (3) and of the reciprocating motion of the sinker (1), on its plane of arrangement, toward and away from the axis (3a) of the needle cylinder (3), have a continuous flat surface.

2. The sinker according to claim 1, characterized in that said laminar body (2) has, below said nose (8), a guiding tab (13), which protrudes from the front side of the laminar body (2) with respect to said nose (8) and can engage in a lower region with respect to an abutment (14) defined by a guiding ring (15) which is fixed coaxially and internally with respect to the needle cylinder (3) of the hosiery knitting machine.

3. The sinker according to claim 1 , characterized in that said laminar body (2) has, to the rear of said nose (8), an actuation heel (16), which protrudes from the upper side of said laminar body (2) and can engage sinker actuation cams.

4. The sinker according to one or more of the preceding claims, characterized in that said laminar body (2) has, proximate to its rear side, an alignment heel (17), which protrudes from its lower side and defines a shoulder (19) which is substantially perpendicular to the lower side (18) of the laminar body (2) and can engage against a circumferential edge (20) of the sinker ring (5) which is directed away from the axis (3a) of the needle cylinder (3) of the circular hosiery knitting machine.

5. The sinker according to one or more of the preceding claims, characterized in that the distance (D) between said knockover plane (9) and the lower side (18) of said laminar body (2) is greater than the maximum distance (F), from said knockover plane (9), of the pivoting axis (24) of the tab (25) of the needles (7) during the maximum lowering that can be imparted to the needles (7) along the corresponding axial slot (6) in order to form a new loop of knitting.
